Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Lidar and Modeling Applications from the Precision Atmospheric Marine Boundary Layer Experiment (PreAMBLE) Dataset
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Precision Atmospheric Marine Boundary Layer Experiment (PreAMBLE) was a field study conducted from 17 May to 17 June 2012 based out of Point Mugu, CA. The central focus was to evaluate atmospheric dynamics associated with the atmospheric marine boundary layer near Point Conception and the California Bight. Airborne measurements were used to evaluate three major topics of research: the coastal jet near Point Conception, the Catalina eddy, and the initiation of coastally trapped wind reversals. PreAMBLE was highly successful and all major goals specified in the original proposal have been completed and published. Three unanticipated outcomes from PreAMBLE have prompted additional research. These include the sheer volume of unique and high quality data obtained, the unanticipated utility of the data collected by the cloud lidar, and the disappointing performance of operational and case-specific numerical simulations. Of the 15 research flights, only five have been required to address key issues from the original proposal. The current project for the remaining ten cases combined with the previous analyses will enable 1) a more comprehensive evaluation of the marine boundary layer characteristics within the Santa Barbara Channel such as height, temperature, and the horizontal pressure field, 2) examine the role of topography in forcing changes in marine boundary layer structure and cloud characteristics near Point Buchon, 3) analysis of marine layer structure, aerosol origin, and fine-scale structure based on the upward- and downward-pointing cloud lidars, and 4) critically evaluate the performance and capability of the Weather Research and Forecasting model in simulating the dynamics, thermodynamics, and cloud cover within the Santa Barbara Channel and near-coastal Pacific Ocean just west of Point Arguello.

Intellectual Merit:
Airborne measurements of the lower atmosphere offshore of southern California are rare since they are difficult to obtain, which makes the PreAMBLE dataset extremely valuable. Important characteristics of the complicated system near Point Conception and the Santa Barbara Channel have been revealed through case studies. Current conceptual models of the dynamics must make assumptions and neglect more complicated issues. These observations allow a critical examination of many of the assumptions. A synthesis of all of the flights during PreAMBLE will provide the community with information on the variability of the fine-scale features and quantify deviations between all cases. Contributions will be made in identifying the relative roles of forcing such as offshore flow and interaction with a complex boundary layer under different conditions. Not only will conceptual models of the dynamics be refined, but a critical examination of the numerical models will be conducted.

Broader Impacts:
The near-coastal environment near Point Conception and the Santa Barbara Channel continue to be of strategic importance. Meteorological phenomena in the marine boundary layer have prompted several major research efforts during the past two decades. Data collected as part of the PreAMBLE field study are among the few airborne measurements taken within this region and are essential for validation of previous conceptual models and provide a hard test for numerical simulations. This project will offer an opportunity for graduate student training in the observational aspects of atmospheric science, a focus that was identified as a key element for the June 2009 Advanced Study Program Colloquium. As with previous field experiments, graduate students from the University of Kansas and the University of Wyoming will become exposed to aircraft datasets and novel applications. The University of Wyoming King Air is a national facility that is available to the entire meteorological community. Advances in aircraft observation techniques including applications of lidar will promote further use by other scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Precision Atmospheric Marine Boundary Layer Experiment (PreAMBLE) was a field study conducted from 17 May to 17 June 2012 based out of Point Mugu, CA. The goal of the project was to examine and document what drives the typically strong wind near the surface offshore of the southern California coast. The strong wind is contained within a cool, moist marine layer extending from the surface to a couple hundred meters above the surface where this marine layer is capped by the warm, dry air aloft. The depth of the marine layer and strong wind have clear links, and the dynamics of this relationship is the focus of this project.

The primary measurement platform was the University of Wyoming King Air, a heavily instrumented research aircraft capable of precise measurements of atmospheric temperature, pressure, humidity, and wind. Topics of research conducted as part of the field study included a) assessment of atmospheric dynamics of the marine boundary layer near Point Conception, b) study of the circulation within the California Bight, commonly known as a Catalina Eddy, and c) study of the development of northward-propagating coastal stratus along the California coast known as a coastally-trapped wind reversal. PreAMBLE was a great success and airborne missions were conducted to address all three topics.

This follow-up study focused on analyzing the aircraft data that was collected during the PreAMBLE study. Three goals were established for this research: (1) expand the analysis of individual PreAMBLE flights, (2) utilize remote sensing measurements from the airborne platform to characterize the marine boundary layer, (3) evaluate the efficacy of numerical model simulations of the marine boundary layer and associated processes near Point Conception and within the Santa Barbara Channel. All three objectives were completed during the study.

Detailed studies were conducted on nearly all fifteen cases conducted during PreAMBLE. The steep coastal terrain of California modulates wind and temperature regimes; adjustment of the marine layer and wind is most pronounced downwind of the Point Arguello/Point Conception headlands. Aircraft measurements from flights conducted on a number of days showed a pronounced thinning of the marine layer downwind of the headlands with a coincident increase in wind speed, which is indicative of a classic hydraulic response. Abrupt changes in the height of the marine layer were often observed. A climatological assessment of atmospheric conditions within the Santa Barbara Channel was made by synthesizing the extensive body of airborne observations.

The University of Wyoming King Air is equipped with remote sensing tools. Extensive use was made of the light detection and ranging (Lidar) instrumentation during PreAMBLE. Such measurement technologies allowed detailed mapping of the marine layer depth along the flight track. Recent studies have rarely observed sudden changes in the marine layer height, known as hydraulic jumps. PreAMBLE provided some of the most detailed spatial representations of the structure of the marine layer ever captured.

To complement the observational data, substantial use was made of computer simulations of the atmosphere using the Weather Research and Forecast model. Numerical simulations were conducted for all cases. Comparisons between airborne observations and model results were made to identify model weaknesses. A common shortcoming of the numerical simulations was the inability to capture the sharp vertical changes near the top of the marine layer. Simulations of the coastally-trapped wind reversals also revealed the sensitivity of the low-level clouds to how they were represented in the model.

One unanticipated discovery from PreAMBLE was an analysis tool using aircraft data that allows the dynamics of a vertical cross section of the atmosphere to be documented. This analysis tool has since been used in subsequent field studies including the Plains Elevated Convection At Night (PECAN) program. Common aircraft vertical sawtooth maneuvers now enable the atmospheric forcing to be directly measured. This is a significant advancement from the goals stated in the original proposal and has implications on the entire atmospheric science community since the University of Wyoming King Air is part of the Earth Observing Facility Fleet and is available to all scientists. Results from PreAMBLE have also prompted innovative technologies using the Lidar that are currently being explored and developed.
